did.abstract: Surgeon specializing in transplant surgery, professor, and Chairman of the Department of Surgery at the University of Michigan. Collection includes publications and presentations, administrative correspondence, biographical records, and documents the history of the Department of Surgery.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received through donations from the Department of Surgery in 2011 (donor no. 10548) and from the Transplant Center (donor no. 10784) and Elizabeth Turcotte in 2012.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the collection are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The papers are open with the exception of some patient/client records.

The Turcotte papers record group includes restricted material in the following categories:
Patient/Client Records -- Boxes 7a

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Jeremiah G. Turcotte papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Jeremiah George Turcotte was born in Detroit, Michigan on January 20, 1933. He attended the University of Michigan, graduating from the Medical School in 1957 with several academic honors. He remained at the University of Michigan for his internship and residency where he was again awarded for his academic achievements. Upon completion of his residency in 1963, Turcotte joined the faculty of the Medical School as an Instructor in Surgery. By 1971, he had become a full professor of surgery and in 1974, he accepted the position of Chairman of the Department of Surgery, a position he held until 1987. He concurrently acted as Head of General Surgery between 1976 and 1981 and often held multiple administrative positions simultaneously during his career. In 2001, Turcotte became a Professor Emeritus of Surgery.

In 1964, Turcotte participated in the first kidney transplant performed at the University of Michigan and transplant surgery eventually became a major focus of his career. He performed the first liver transplant at the University in 1985 and consistently worked with transplantation at the university, directing the Surgery Transplant Program, the Organ Transplantation Center, the Transplant and Health Policy Center, and the Liver Transplant Program during his career. He also published numerous articles and book chapters on the subject, as well as publishing widely on his other research interests, which included portal hypertension and liver disease. Over his career, his work resulted in more than 195 published journal articles, eight books, and 55 book chapters. He presented just as prolifically, and was invited to lecture throughout the U.S. and internationally.

Along with his service in various organizations and centers at the University, Turcotte was also active in numerous national organizations. He was a founding member of the American Society of Transplant Surgeons and the Transplantation Society of Michigan (later the Gift of Life Foundation). He served as president of these societies, as well as the Central Surgical Association, and the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS), the Michigan Chapter of the American College of Surgeons. He served in leadership positions for numerous other organizations and societies, as well.

Amid his many other responsibilities, Turcotte took an interest in the history of the Department of Surgery and gathered numerous materials documenting that history, starting as far back as Moses Gunn, the first professor of surgery at the University of Michigan. He later served on the 150th Anniversary Celebration Committee and assisted in creating a book documenting the Department's history.

Turcotte was the recipient of numerous awards and honors throughout his career. He received the Russel Award from the University of Michigan in 1970 and held the Frederick A. Coller Professorship from 1979 to1989. In 2002, not long after his retirement, the updated surgical library was dedicated in his honor. In 2004, he was given the Distinguished Service Award by the University of Michigan Medical Center Alumni Society, and in 2006, the Jeremiah and Claire Turcotte Professorship in Transplantation Surgery was inaugurated. He also received awards from non-University sources, including the Champion of Hope Award from the National Kidney Foundation in 1996 and the ASTS-Roche Pioneer award in 2005.

scopecontent.p: The Jeremiah G. Turcotte papers document the career of Turcotte, a transplant surgeon at the University of Michigan, and the history of the Department of Surgery. The collection consists of 11 linear feet and dates from 1933 to 2012, with majority of records dating from 1961 to 2001. The collection has eight series: Personal Files, Publications, Presentations, History, Chairman Records, Patient Records, Audio-Visual Materials, and Slides.

scopecontent.p: The Personal Files series (0.75 linear feet) includes records related to. Turcotte's personal life and career. Material includes awards and honors received by Turcotte, records relating to various societies and organizations he was a member of, and his professional activity, including his Curriculum Vitae, which includes both a paper copy and a copy on CD. The series also includes a transcript of an interview with the Center for the History of Medicine, which contains extensive biographical information. A copy of the transcript is also included on the CD containing Turcotte's CV.

did.unittitle: Inauguration of the Jeremiah and Claire Turcotte Professorship in Transplantation Surgery 2006-2007
Frederick A. Coller Surgical Society Presidential Address -- "Chirurgia, Change, and Coller," 1983
Transplant Society of Michigan Gift of Life Foundation 2001-2008
Transcript of Center for the History of Medicine Interview 2006

scopecontent.p: The Publications series (1.25 linear feet) documents Turcotte's publishing history. The series is arranged by publications listed on Turcotte's Curriculum Vitae and publications not on his CV. Articles in the Curriculum Vitae Publications Subseries are arranged based on the categories listed on the CV, then further arranged numerically based on the order publications are listed on Turcotte's CV.

did.unittitle: "The Anencephalic Infant as an Organ Donor for Transplantation: Ethical, Medical and Legal Considerations," undated
"Cyclosporine dosing and timing: Impact upon allograft outcome, hospitalization time and the cost in the young pediatric kidney transplant recipient," undated
"An Empirical Approach to Liver Transplantation for the Alcoholic," undated
"GD-MRA in the Evaluation of Vascular Complications Following Liver Transplantation," 1997
"Hepatic Transplantation," Surgery of the Alimentary Tract, 5th Edition, 2000
"Incidence and Management of Biliary Complications after 291 Liver Transplants Following the Introduction of Transcystic Stenting," undated
"Infra-hepatic Auxiliary Transplantation with Preservation of the Entire Native Liver in the Treatment of Crigler Najjar Syndrome Type I," 1997
"The MELD System in Liver Transplantation: What Is It, How to Use It, What Will It Mean?" 2002
"The New Liver Allocation Policy: A Starting Point," undated
"Portal Hypertension," Surgery: Scientific Principles and Practices, 2nd Edition, 1994
"The Potential of Presensitization as a Prognostic Factor in Cadaveric Renal Transplantation," undated
"Recent Advances in the Treatment of Shock," undated

scopecontent.p: The Presentations series (0.75 linear feet) documents lectures, presentations, and talks given by Turcotte. The first part of series, the Talks subseries, contains lists of slides used for 247 presentations given by Turcotte and is tied to the Slides series. The list of slides for presentations includes the category and slide number of each slide used in the presentation. The Presentations series also includes presentations listed on Turcotte's CV. These presentations are arranged numerically based on their listing on the CV. Finally, there are materials for presentations not listed elsewhere.

did.unittitle: Resident Talk -- Kidney Transplantation/Overview of US Transplant System 2004
"The Story of Transplantation: From Myth to Mice to Man" Student Talk 2004-2005
"Surgery and Surgeons at the University of Michigan," 1981
"Transplantation: A Frontier for Bioethics and Bioscience," undated
Variceal Bleeding in Cirrhosis of the Liver Panel Discussion 1976

scopecontent.p: The History series (3.5 linear feet) documents the history of the Department of Surgery at the University of Michigan, and dates back to the 1850s. The series includes a subseries documenting the lives of various notable professors of surgery at the University of Michigan, one documenting the history of the Department of Surgery, and a photographs series.

did.unittitle: Creation of Section of General Surgery 1966-1967
"The University of Michigan Eye Center: A Centennial Project 1981
General Surgery Staff and Class Pictures 1938-1982

scopecontent.p: The Chairman Records series (0.5 linear feet) includes records from Turcotte's service as Chairman of the Department of Surgery. The series includes correspondence between various administrators and reports.

did.unittitle: Frey, Charles W. (Wayne County General Hospital) 1974

scopecontent.p: The Patient Records series (0.5 linear feet) includes operation records from Turcotte's residency, and early transplant records, including patient records from a Home Records Book. Records were removed from the Home Records Book binder and foldered by patient.
The Audio-Visual series (1 linear foot) includes a variety of media, including 16mm film, VHS cassette tapes, and mini-cassette tapes.

did.unittitle: Intra Uterine Kidney Transplant -- Film Reel
Hepatic Resection with the Ultrasonic Knife
Extraperitoneal Cystic Duct Drainage of the Bile Duct in Liver Transplantation

scopecontent.p: The Slides series (3 linear feet) includes file cabinets of slides used in various presentations given by Turcotte (see the Presentations series). The slides are housed in the original cabinets in the order maintained by Turcotte and are accompanied by a binder listing slides by category and number and giving a description of the contents of each slide. The slides include a variety of content such as diagrams, surgical procedures, facilities, and historical images.
